info.title: Mallory Core API - Public
info.description: Public API - Threat intelligence platform API (private endpoints excluded)

get.description: Endpoint to browse for threat actors, with filters on some criteria.

parameters.name: filter

schema.description:
A string used to filter threat actors. It can start with specific prefixes to indicate the type of filter:
- `name:`: Filter by Name, case-insensitive.
- `uuid:`: Filter by UUID, case-insensitive.
- `internal_name:`: Filter by internal_name (exact match).
- `desc:`: Filter by description (searches both description and gen_description fields).
If no prefix is provided, it defaults to filtering on the display_name or name fields.
Examples:
- `name:APT`
- `name:lazarus_group`
- `internal_name:m-threat-actor-happy-yellow-dog-a123`
- `lazarus_group`
- `Lazarus Group`
schema.title: Filter

get.description:
Compare trending threat actors between two adjacent time periods.

"Trending" is defined as the top N entities by mention count, where N
is controlled by the `trending_limit` parameter (default: 10).

Uses a sliding window approach where the current period ends at now,
and the baseline period ends where the current period starts.

Returns items categorized as:
- **newly_trending**: In top N current but not in top N baseline
- **no_longer_trending**: In top N baseline but not in top N current
- **still_trending**: In top N for both periods

Example with window=1d, trending_limit=20:
- current_period: (now - 1 day) to now, top 20 by mentions
- baseline_period: (now - 2 days) to (now - 1 day), top 20 by mentions

parameters.name: window

schema.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.
schema.title: Window

parameters.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.

parameters.name: trending_limit

schema.description: Maximum number of entities to consider as 'trending' per period. Only the top N entities by mention count are compared. Default: 10.
schema.title: Trending Limit

parameters.description: Maximum number of entities to consider as 'trending' per period. Only the top N entities by mention count are compared. Default: 10.

get.description:
Export complete threat actor profile with all related data.

Returns the threat actor data along with arrays of:
- aliases: Known aliases for this threat actor
- mentions: References in threat intelligence sources
- observables: Associated IoCs (IP addresses, domains, hashes, URLs)

Use the optional timestamp parameters to filter related entities by their
creation date. This is useful for incremental exports.

get.description:
Endpoint to browse attack patterns (MITRE ATT&CK techniques),
with filters on various criteria.

parameters.name: filter

schema.description:
A string used to filter attack patterns. It can start with specific prefixes to indicate the type of filter:
- `mitre_id:`: Filter by MITRE ATT&CK ID (e.g., 'mitre_id:T1566').
- `tactic:`: Filter by tactic (e.g., 'tactic:initial-access').
- `name:`: Filter by name (partial match, case-insensitive).
- `subtechnique:`: Filter by subtechnique status ('subtechnique:true' or 'subtechnique:false').
- `uuid:`: Filter by UUID.
If no prefix is provided, it defaults to a name filter.
schema.title: Filter

- `name:`: Filter by name (partial match, case-insensitive).
- `subtechnique:`: Filter by subtechnique status ('subtechnique:true' or 'subtechnique:false').
- `uuid:`: Filter by UUID.
If no prefix is provided, it defaults to a name filter.

get.description:
Endpoint to browse for breaches, with filters
on some criteria.

parameters.name: filter

schema.description:
A string used to filter breaches. It can start with specific prefixes to indicate the type of filter:
- `name:`: Filter by Name, case-insensitive.
- `uuid:`: Filter by UUID (exact match).
- `internal_name:`: Filter by internal_name (exact match).
- `loss_type:`: Filter by loss type (array contains).
- `record_type:`: Filter by affected record type (array contains).
If no prefix is provided, it defaults to filtering on the display_name or name fields.
Examples:
- `name:Adobe`
- `internal_name:adobe`
- `loss_type:Passwords`
- `record_type:Email addresses`

get.description: Endpoint to browse for exploitations.

parameters.name: filter

schema.description:
Filter the exploitations by vulnerability_uuid, cve_id, source, begins_at, or ends_at.  It can start with specific prefixes to indicate the type of filter:
- `vulnerability_uuid:`: Filter by vulnerability UUID.
- `cve_id:`: Filter by CVE ID.
- `source:`: Filter by source.
- `begins_at{operator}`: Filter by begins_at.  Allowed operators are: <, <=, =, >=, > (e.g. `begins_at>2025-11-01`)
- `ends_at{operator}`: Filter by ends_at.  Allowed operators are: <, <=, =, >=, > (e.g. `ends_at<2025-11-01`)
- If no prefix is provided, it defaults to filtering on the vulnerability_uuid, cve_id, and source fields.

get.description:
Get the GICS (Global Industry Classification Standard) hierarchy.

Returns the complete GICS hierarchy organized as:
Sectors -> Industry Groups -> Industries -> Sub-Industries.

Use this data for industry selection in tenant configuration
or filtering by industry classification.

Get a specific GICS industry by its 6-digit code.

Returns the industry with all its sub-industries.
Returns 404 if the industry code does not exist.

post.description:
Create a new integration for the current tenant.

Sensitive data is encrypted before storage and never returned in responses.
The request body is validated against type-specific schemas based on the 'type' field.

get.description:
List all integrations for the current tenant.

Sensitive data is never included in responses.

Query Parameters:
    filter: Optional filter string
        - "type:slack" - filter by exact type match
        - "name:foo" - filter by name containing "foo" (case-insensitive)
        - "foo" - same as "name:foo"
    offset: Number of items to skip (default: 0)
    limit: Maximum number of items to return (default: 500, max: 500)

get.description:
Get available capabilities for all registered integration types.

Returns a mapping of integration type to list of supported actions.

Get JSON schemas for all registered integration types.

Returns schemas for credentials, configuration, and action payloads for each type,
along with the type's supported capabilities.

Get a specific integration by UUID.

Only returns integrations belonging to the current tenant.
Sensitive data is never included in responses.

patch.description:
Update an existing integration.

If sensitive_data is provided, it will be validated against the type-specific
schema and re-encrypted. Sensitive data is never included in responses.

delete.description:
Delete an integration.

Only allows deletion of integrations belonging to the current tenant.

By default, if the integration is used by schedules, returns HTTP 409 Conflict
with the list of affected schedules without deleting. Set force=true to proceed
with deletion.

When force=true, the integration_uuid will be cleared from all associated
schedules before deletion.

Returns:
    - 200: Integration deleted successfully
    - 404: Integration not found
    - 409: Integration is in use by schedules (requires force=true)

parameters.name: force

schema.description: Force deletion even if schedules are using this integration
schema.title: Force

parameters.description: Force deletion even if schedules are using this integration

post.description:
Execute an action on an integration.

Available actions depend on the integration type's capabilities:
- test: Test the integration connection
- execute: Execute an outbound action (e.g., send message)

get.description:
Compare trending malware between two adjacent time periods.

"Trending" is defined as the top N entities by mention count, where N
is controlled by the `trending_limit` parameter (default: 10).

Uses a sliding window approach where the current period ends at now,
and the baseline period ends where the current period starts.

Returns items categorized as:
- **newly_trending**: In top N current but not in top N baseline
- **no_longer_trending**: In top N baseline but not in top N current
- **still_trending**: In top N for both periods

Example with window=1d, trending_limit=20:
- current_period: (now - 1 day) to now, top 20 by mentions
- baseline_period: (now - 2 days) to (now - 1 day), top 20 by mentions

parameters.name: window

schema.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.
schema.title: Window

parameters.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.

parameters.name: trending_limit

schema.description: Maximum number of entities to consider as 'trending' per period. Only the top N entities by mention count are compared. Default: 10.
schema.title: Trending Limit

parameters.description: Maximum number of entities to consider as 'trending' per period. Only the top N entities by mention count are compared. Default: 10.

get.description: Endpoint to browse for organizations, with filters on some criteria.

parameters.name: filter

schema.description:
A string used to filter organizations. It can start with specific prefixes to indicate the type of filter:
- `name:`: Filter by Name, case-insensitive.
- `uuid:`: Filter by UUID, case-insensitive.
- `internal_name:`: Filter by internal_name (exact match).
- `desc:`: Filter by description (searches both description and gen_description fields).
If no prefix is provided, it defaults to filtering on the display_name or name fields.
Examples:
- `name:Microsoft`
- `name:apple`
- `internal_name:microsoft_corporation`
- `Microsoft Corporation`
schema.title: Filter

parameters.description:
A string used to filter organizations. It can start with specific prefixes to indicate the type of filter:
- `name:`: Filter by Name, case-insensitive.
- `uuid:`: Filter by UUID, case-insensitive.
- `internal_name:`: Filter by internal_name (exact match).
- `desc:`: Filter by description (searches both description and gen_description fields).
If no prefix is provided, it defaults to filtering on the display_name or name fields.
Examples:
- `name:Microsoft`

get.description:
Compare trending organizations between two adjacent time periods.

"Trending" is defined as the top N entities by mention count, where N
is controlled by the `trending_limit` parameter (default: 10).

Uses a sliding window approach where the current period ends at now,
and the baseline period ends where the current period starts.

Returns items categorized as:
- **newly_trending**: In top N current but not in top N baseline
- **no_longer_trending**: In top N baseline but not in top N current
- **still_trending**: In top N for both periods

Example with window=1d, trending_limit=20:
- current_period: (now - 1 day) to now, top 20 by mentions
- baseline_period: (now - 2 days) to (now - 1 day), top 20 by mentions

parameters.name: window

schema.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.
schema.title: Window

parameters.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.

schema.description: Maximum number of entities to consider as 'trending' per period. Only the top N entities by mention count are compared. Default: 10.
schema.title: Trending Limit

get.description:
Get paginated list of stories.

Stories are collections of related references that have been clustered together
based on content similarity and temporal proximity.

Date filtering is handled by the StoryFilter via TimestampFilterMixin, using
parameters like created_at__gte, created_at__lt, updated_at__gte, updated_at__lt.

parameters.name: filter

schema.description:
A string used to filter stories. Allowed filter terms:
- `title:`: filter by title (case insensitive substring)
- `description:`: filter by description (case insensitive substring)
- `min_refs:`: filter by minimum reference count (e.g., min_refs:5)
- `max_refs:`: filter by maximum reference count (e.g., max_refs:10)
- `topic:`: filter by topic labels (comma-separated, OR logic, e.g., topic:ransomware,malware)
- If no prefix is provided, the filter will search in the title.

get.description:
Get focus entities for a specific story with saliency scores.

Returns entities that are central to the story, grouped by entity type.
Each entity includes its saliency score indicating how important it is to the story.
Saliency score is calculated as the inner product similarity between entity
mention contexts and story embedding.

Results are grouped by type (vulnerabilities, threat_actors, malware,
technology_vendors, technology_products, organizations) and sorted by saliency
score (highest first) within each group.

A string used to filter vulnerabilities. It can start with specific prefixes to indicate the type of filter:
- `cve:`: Filter by CVE ID.
- `uuid:`: Filter by UUID.
- `internal_name:`: Filter by internal_name (exact match).
- `desc:`: Filter by description (searches both description and gen_description fields).
- `gen_display_name:`: Filter by gen_display_name.
- `cisa_kev:`: Filter by cisa_kev.
- `state:`: Filter by state.
- If the filter string matches the pattern `CVE-` or a UUID pattern, it will be treated as a specific filter.
- If no prefix is provided, it defaults to a description filter (searches both description fields).

get.description:
Compare trending vulnerabilities between two adjacent time periods.

"Trending" is defined as the top N entities by mention count, where N
is controlled by the `trending_limit` parameter (default: 10).

Uses a sliding window approach where the current period ends at now,
and the baseline period ends where the current period starts.

Returns items categorized as:
- **newly_trending**: In top N current but not in top N baseline
- **no_longer_trending**: In top N baseline but not in top N current
- **still_trending**: In top N for both periods

Example with window=1d, trending_limit=20:
- current_period: (now - 1 day) to now, top 20 by mentions
- baseline_period: (now - 2 days) to (now - 1 day), top 20 by mentions

parameters.name: window

schema.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.
schema.title: Window

parameters.description: Time window for comparison. Format: '<number><unit>' where unit is 'd' (days) or 'h' (hours). Examples: '1d', '12h', '7d'. Maximum: 30d or 720h. Default: '1d'.

parameters.name: trending_limit

schema.description: Maximum number of entities to consider as 'trending' per period. Only the top N entities by mention count are compared. Default: 10.
schema.title: Trending Limit

parameters.description: Maximum number of entities to consider as 'trending' per period. Only the top N entities by mention count are compared. Default: 10.

get.description:
Export complete vulnerability intelligence with all related entities.

Returns the vulnerability data along with arrays of:
- exploits: Known exploits targeting this vulnerability
- exploitations: Recorded exploitation incidents
- mentions: References in threat intelligence sources
- detection_signatures: Detection rules for this vulnerability
- vulnerable_configurations: Affected product configurations
- advisories: Vendor security advisories

Use the optional timestamp parameters to filter related entities by their
creation date. This is useful for incremental exports.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary, most commonly used name of the agency being discussed. Include both regulatory bodies (SEC, FDA, EPA, CISA) and law enforcement agencies (FBI, Europol, Scotland Yard). Examples: FDA, FBI, CISA, Europol, SEC, FTC, ICO, CNIL

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names, abbreviations, or full formal names for the agency as mentioned in the content. Examples: ['Food and Drug Administration'] for FDA, ['Federal Bureau of Investigation'] for FBI, ['Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency'] for CISA, ['European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation'] for Europol

countries.title: Countries
countries.description: A list of countries or jurisdictions to which the agency belongs as mentioned in the content. Use alpha-2 ISO3166 format. Examples: ['US'], ['GB'], ['DE', 'FR'], ['JP']

regulatory_domains.title: Regulatory Domains
regulatory_domains.description: A list of regulatory domains or areas of authority for this body as mentioned in the content. Examples: ['cybersecurity'], ['data protection'], ['financial services'], ['telecommunications', 'healthcare'], ['privacy'], ['law enforcement'], ['national security']

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the agency is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'The SEC announced new cybersecurity disclosure requirements for public companies following recent high-profile breaches...', 'The FBI issued a warning about ransomware attacks...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview or summary of the agency's role or significance based on the content. This should capture why the agency is relevant to the discussion. Examples: 'Federal agency responsible for cybersecurity oversight and incident response', 'Law enforcement agency investigating cybercrime', 'Data protection authority enforcing GDPR compliance'

enforcement_actions.title: Enforcement Actions
enforcement_actions.description: A list of enforcement actions, penalties, or regulatory measures mentioned in the content. Examples: 'Issued $50M fine for data breach', 'Required mandatory breach notification', 'Imposed consent decree', 'Arrested cybercriminals', 'Seized criminal infrastructure'

regulatory_changes.title: Regulatory Changes
regulatory_changes.description: A list of new regulations, rule changes, or policy updates mentioned in the content. Examples: 'New cybersecurity reporting requirements', 'Updated privacy regulations', 'Enhanced breach notification rules'

affected_industries.title: Affected Industries
affected_industries.description: A list of industries affected by the agency's actions as mentioned in the content. Use single words when possible. Examples: finance, healthcare, technology, telecommunications, energy

compliance_requirements.title: Compliance Requirements
compliance_requirements.description: A list of specific compliance requirements or obligations mentioned in the content. Examples: 'Annual cybersecurity assessments', 'Incident reporting within 72 hours', 'Data protection impact assessments'

announcement_date.title: Announcement Date
announcement_date.description: The date when regulatory actions, changes, or announcements were made as mentioned in the content. Convert to ISO format (YYYY-MM-DD)

AgencyAnnouncementAnalysis.title: AgencyAnnouncementAnalysis
AgencyAnnouncementAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single agency announcement from the content.

Include both regulatory agencies (SEC, FDA, EPA, CISA) and law enforcement agencies
(FBI, Europol, Scotland Yard). These are government bodies making official
announcements, not private organizations.

AliasClaimOutputModel.description: Basic output model for alias claims.

type.title: Type
type.description: Type of alias. Must be one of: agency, attack_pattern, breach, malware, organization, technology_product, threat_actor, vulnerability

external_display_name.title: External Display Name
external_display_name.description: Display name as it appears in the source

AliasCreate.description: Schema for creating a new alias.

type.title: Type
type.description: Type of alias. Must be one of: agency, attack_pattern, breach, malware, organization, technology_product, threat_actor, vulnerability

external_display_name.title: External Display Name
external_display_name.description: Display name as it appears in the source

deprecated.title: Deprecated
deprecated.description: Set to true to deprecate alias (sets deprecated_at to now), false to un-deprecate (clears deprecated_at)

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary attack pattern name or MITRE ATT&CK technique being discussed. These should generally correspond with MITRE ATT&CK. Use the most commonly referenced name in the content. Examples: Phishing, SQL Injection, Spear Phishing, Command and Control, Lateral Movement

mitre_attack_id.title: Mitre Attack Id
mitre_attack_id.description: A MITRE ATT&CK technique ID or variant mentioned in the text, if available. Include any alternative technique IDs or variants mentioned. Examples: T1566, T1566.001, T1598.002. If it's not clear or no ID is mentioned, leave blank.

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the attack pattern is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'The threat actor used spear-phishing emails with malicious attachments to gain initial access to the target network...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview or summary of how this attack pattern is being used or discussed in the content. Focus on the specific implementation or context mentioned. If not clearly described, return None.

associated_threat_actors.title: Associated Threat Actors
associated_threat_actors.description: A list of threat actors or groups that are mentioned as using this technique or tactic. Include both formal names and aliases when mentioned. Examples: APT28, Fancy Bear, Lazarus Group, FIN7

associated_malware.title: Associated Malware
associated_malware.description: A list of malware families or tools that are mentioned as being used in conjunction with this technique or tactic. Examples: Cobalt Strike, Emotet, TrickBot, Mimikatz

AttackPatternAnalysis.title: AttackPatternAnalysis
AttackPatternAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single attack pattern or TTP from the content.

These should generally correspond with MITRE ATT&CK techniques and tactics.
Focus on named Attack Patterns and TTPs (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures).

AttackPatternDetailOutputModel.title: AttackPatternDetailOutputModel
AttackPatternDetailOutputModel.description: Model for detailed attack pattern output

AttackPatternOutputModel.title: AttackPatternOutputModel
AttackPatternOutputModel.description: Model for basic attack pattern output

BaseEntityOutputModel.title: BaseEntityOutputModel
BaseEntityOutputModel.description:
Base output model for all entities with common fields.

This consolidates the common output fields that appear across all entity output models.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The name or identifier of the breach event if mentioned in the content. This could be a formal name given to the incident, a reference number, or how the breach is commonly referred to. Examples: Equifax Breach, SolarWinds Hack, Target Data Breach, Operation Aurora

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the breach is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'The Equifax data breach exposed sensitive information of 147 million consumers including Social Security numbers, birth dates, and addresses...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview or summary of the breach event based on the content. This should capture the key aspects of the incident including what happened, who was affected, and the impact. Examples: 'Major data breach affecting millions of customers due to compromised database servers, resulting in exposure of personal and financial information'

associated_threat_actors.title: Associated Threat Actors
associated_threat_actors.description: Names or aliases of the threat actors, hacker groups, or entities attributed to the breach. These may include individuals, collectives, or nation-state actors believed to be responsible. If multiple are mentioned, list them all. Examples: APT29, Lazarus Group, Anonymous, FIN7, Scattered Spider.

loss_types.title: Loss Types
loss_types.description: The type of loss that occurred from the breach, such as Data Breach, Financial Loss, or Reputation Damage. Examples: Data Breach, Financial Loss, Reputation Damage, Intellectual Property Theft, Service Disruption

loss_description.title: Loss Description
loss_description.description: A detailed description of the loss that occurred, such as records lost or monetary loss. Include any specific details that are discussed in the text. Examples: Personal records of customers were leaked to unauthorized parties, Financial loss incurred due to fraudulent transactions

affected_primary_victim.title: Affected Primary Victim
affected_primary_victim.description: The name of the primary organization or entity directly compromised in the incident. Use the full name of corporations and municipalities (e.g., 'State of Colorado' vs 'Colorado', 'City of Minnetonka' vs 'Minnetonka', 'City of Columbus'). Do not include words like 'ransomware attack' or 'breach' in the names. Provide only the organization or entity name itself, not details about specific systems, platforms, or instances. Examples: Equifax, City of Columbus, Yahoo, Yahoo Inc

affected_downstream_victims.title: Affected Downstream Victims
affected_downstream_victims.description: Names of organizations or entities indirectly impacted by the breach. Use full names for corporations and municipalities. Do not include incident words like 'breach' or 'attack' in the names. Provide only the organization or entity names themselves, not details about specific systems, platforms, or instances. These may include clients, partners, or customers whose data or credentials were exposed through the primary victim's systems.

date_occurred.title: Date Occurred
date_occurred.description: The date when the breach event actually occurred in YYYY-MM-DD format. This may be an estimate. Examples: 2024-05-01, 2023-11-15

date_detected.title: Date Detected
date_detected.description: The date when the breach event was detected in YYYY-MM-DD format. Examples: 2024-05-05, 2023-11-18

date_reported.title: Date Reported
date_reported.description: The date when the breach event was publicly announced in YYYY-MM-DD format. Examples: 2024-05-10, 2023-11-20

loss_amount.title: Loss Amount
loss_amount.description: The amount of financial loss, if discussed in the text.

BreachAnalysis.title: BreachAnalysis
BreachAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single data breach event from the content.

Focus on organizations that suffered from a data breach. Use the full name of
corporations and municipalities (e.g., 'State of Colorado' vs 'Colorado',
'City of Minnetonka' vs 'Minnetonka'). Do not include words like 'ransomware attack'
or 'breach' in the organization names.

BreachDetailOutputModel.title: BreachDetailOutputModel
BreachDetailOutputModel.description: Detailed output model for Breach entity.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary actor intrusion set or campaign name being discussed. Use the most commonly referenced name in the content. If no specific name is provided, you can construct a name starting with descriptors and appending 'Campaign' as the primary name. Examples: Operation Aurora, Bitcoin Email Campaign, Game-related Applications Campaign, Hidden Risk Campaign, SolarWinds Supply Chain Attack, Volt Typhoon Financial Firm Exploitation Campaign

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names, code names, or synonyms used to refer to the campaign as mentioned in the content. Include operational names, internal designations, and researcher-assigned names. Examples: SUNBURST, UNC2452, Dark Halo, Hidden Risk Campaign

campaign_type.title: Campaign Type
campaign_type.description: The type or category of campaign being discussed. Examples: Espionage Campaign, Ransomware Campaign, Supply Chain Attack, Influence Operation, Cyber Warfare, APT Campaign, Financial Crime Campaign

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the campaign is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'Operation Aurora was a sophisticated cyber attack campaign that targeted major corporations including Google, Adobe, and other technology companies...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview or summary of the campaign based on the content. Focus on the key objectives, methods, and impact mentioned. Examples: 'Multi-stage espionage campaign targeting government agencies to steal classified information', 'Ransomware campaign targeting healthcare organizations during COVID-19 pandemic'

attributed_threat_actors.title: Attributed Threat Actors
attributed_threat_actors.description: A list of threat actors attributed to or associated with this campaign as mentioned in the content. Only include proper threat actor names, not generic terms. Examples: APT28, Lazarus Group, FIN7, Cozy Bear

targeted_sectors.title: Targeted Sectors
targeted_sectors.description: A list of industry sectors or verticals targeted by this campaign as mentioned in the content. Use broad sector categories. Examples: government, healthcare, finance, energy, technology, defense

targeted_countries.title: Targeted Countries
targeted_countries.description: A list of countries or regions targeted by this campaign as mentioned in the content. Use country names or broader regional designations. Examples: United States, European Union, Southeast Asia, Ukraine

attack_vectors.title: Attack Vectors
attack_vectors.description: A list of attack vectors or initial access methods used in this campaign as mentioned in the content. Focus on the primary methods described. Examples: spear-phishing, supply chain compromise, watering hole attacks, vulnerability exploitation

malware_used.title: Malware Used
malware_used.description: A list of malware families or tools used in this campaign as mentioned in the content. Include both custom and commodity malware. Examples: SUNBURST, Cobalt Strike, Mimikatz, custom backdoor

vulnerabilities_exploited.title: Vulnerabilities Exploited
vulnerabilities_exploited.description: A list of vulnerabilities exploited in this campaign as mentioned in the content. Include CVE IDs and vulnerability names when available. Examples: CVE-2020-1472, Zerologon, CVE-2021-44228, Log4Shell

timeline.title: Timeline
timeline.description: Timeline information about the campaign as mentioned in the content. This could include start dates, duration, or key milestones. Examples: 'Active since March 2020', 'Discovered in December 2020', 'Campaign lasted from 2019 to 2021'

objectives.title: Objectives
objectives.description: A list of campaign objectives or goals as mentioned in the content. Focus on the strategic purposes described. Examples: data theft, espionage, financial gain, disruption, intelligence gathering, credential harvesting

impact_description.title: Impact Description
impact_description.description: Description of the campaign's impact as mentioned in the content. Include scope, scale, and consequences when described. Examples: 'Affected over 18,000 organizations worldwide', 'Resulted in theft of sensitive government documents'

CampaignAnalysis.title: CampaignAnalysis
CampaignAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single actor intrusion set or campaign from content.

If no specific campaign name is provided in the content, you can construct a name
by starting with descriptors and appending ' Campaign' as the primary name.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary defensive pattern name or security control being discussed. Use the most commonly referenced name in the content. This could be a security control, mitigation technique, or protective strategy. Examples: Multi-Factor Authentication, Endpoint Detection and Response, Network Segmentation

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names, abbreviations, or variants for this defensive pattern as mentioned in the content. Include common abbreviations. Examples: ['MFA', '2FA'] for Multi-Factor Authentication, ['EDR'] for Endpoint Detection and Response

control_type.title: Control Type
control_type.description: The type or category of defensive control being described. Examples: Preventive, Detective, Corrective, Administrative, Technical, Physical

nist_framework_reference.title: Nist Framework Reference
nist_framework_reference.description: A NIST Cybersecurity Framework reference for the defensive pattern discussed in the content. Be as specific as possible. Must be a valid NIST CSF function, category, or subcategory. If it's not clear, it can be left blank. Examples: ID.AM-1, PR.AC-1, DE.AE-2, RS.RP-1, RC.RP-1

d3fend_id.title: D3Fend Id
d3fend_id.description: A MITRE D3FEND technique identifier for the defensive pattern from https://d3fend.mitre.org/discussed in the content. D3FEND IDs follow the format 'D3-XXX' where XXX is a 2-4 character abbreviation. Only include if there's a clear mapping to a specific D3FEND defensive technique. Examples: D3-MFA (Multi-Factor Authentication), D3-NM (Network Monitoring), D3-AC (Access Control), D3-EDR (Endpoint Detection and Response), D3-NS (Network Segmentation), D3-AI (Asset Inventory)

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the defensive pattern is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'The organization implemented multi-factor authentication across all user accounts to prevent unauthorized access...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview or summary of how this defensive pattern is being used or discussed in the content. Focus on the specific implementation or context mentioned. If not clearly described, return None.

implementation_details.title: Implementation Details
implementation_details.description: Specific details about how this defensive pattern is implemented or should be implemented according to the content. Include technical details, configuration requirements, or deployment considerations if mentioned.

effectiveness_notes.title: Effectiveness Notes
effectiveness_notes.description: Any notes about the effectiveness of this defensive pattern mentioned in the content. This could include success rates, limitations, or conditions under which it works best.

DefensivePatternAnalysis.title: DefensivePatternAnalysis
DefensivePatternAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single defensive pattern or security control.

Focus on specific defensive measures, security tools, or protective strategies
mentioned in the content. Include abbreviations as aliases (e.g., MFA for
Multi-Factor Authentication, EDR for Endpoint Detection and Response).

version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The actual indicator name/value. Examples: evil.com, 192.168.1.1, d41d8cd98f00b204e9800998ecf8427e, infected-host, 0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc454e4438f44e

type.title: Type
type.description:
The type of indicator using type.subtype format. Valid types MUST be one of the following:
Core observables: ip.v4, ip.v6, cidr.v4, cidr.v6, domain, hostname, uri, email, asn, mac
DNS records: dns.a, dns.aaaa, dns.cname, dns.mx, dns.ns, dns.txt, dns.soa, dns.srv, dns.ptr, dns.caa
Network: port.tcp, port.udp, port.sctp, service
Hashes: hash.md5, hash.sha1, hash.sha256, hash.sha512, hash.ssdeep, hash.tlsh, hash.imphash, hash.pehash
Certificates: cert.sha1, cert.sha256, cert.serial, cert.subject, cert.issuer, cert.spki_sha256
HTTP/TLS: http.user_agent, ja3, ja3s, hja3
Process: process.name, process.cmdline, registry.key
Cloud: aws.account_id, aws.arn, aws.role, aws.instance_id, aws.s3_bucket, azure.tenant_id, azure.subscription_id, azure.object_id, azure.resource_id, gcp.project_id, gcp.project_number, gcp.service_account, gcp.gcs_bucket
Mobile: imei, imsi, iccid, msisdn
Crypto: crypto_addr.btc, crypto_addr.eth, crypto_addr.xmr, crypto_addr.ltc, crypto_addr.usdt_eth, crypto_addr.usdt_tron, tx_hash.btc, tx_hash.eth, tx_hash.tron, tx_hash.etc
Code/packages: software_package.npm, software_package.pypi, software_package.maven, software_package.rubygems, software_package.nuget, software_package.go, software_package.cargo, software_package.packagist, git.commit, git.repo_url, git.tag, repo.dockerhub
Social: handle.twitter, handle.github, handle.telegram, handle.discord, handle.reddit, channel.telegram, channel.discord
Finance: iban, swift_bic, cc_bin
Extensions: extension.browser_chrome_id, extension.browser_edge_id, extension.browser_firefox_guid, extension.browser_safari_bundle_id, extension.browser_listing_url, extension.vscode_extension_id, extension.vscode_marketplace_url

context.title: Context
context.description: A brief one-line explanation of why this indicator was identified as malicious or suspicious based on the content. Examples: 'Command and control server for Emotet malware', 'Malicious payload hash distributed in phishing campaign', 'Compromised domain hosting exploit kit', 'Bitcoin wallet used for ransomware payments'

verdict.title: Verdict
verdict.description: The verdict about this indicator based on how it is characterized in the content. Must be one of: 'malicious', 'benign', 'suspicious', 'unknown'. Use 'malicious' if the content explicitly identifies the indicator as malicious or associated with threats. Use 'suspicious' if the content suggests potential malicious activity but is not definitive. Use 'benign' if explicitly stated as safe. Use 'unknown' or None if the content does not provide enough information to determine the verdict. Examples: 'malicious' for known C2 servers, 'suspicious' for newly registered domains with unusual patterns.

confidence.title: Confidence
confidence.description: The confidence level that the verdict chosen for this indicator is accurate based on the content. Examples: high, medium, low. If not explicitly mentioned in the content, return None.

first_seen.title: First Seen
first_seen.description: When this indicator was first observed, if mentioned in the content. Examples: '2024-01-15', 'January 2024', 'last week'. If not mentioned, return None.

last_seen.title: Last Seen
last_seen.description: When this indicator was last observed, if mentioned in the content. Examples: '2024-01-20', 'February 2024', 'yesterday'. If not mentioned, return None.

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: Relevant tags or categories associated with this indicator as mentioned in the content. Examples: ['c2', 'malware'], ['phishing', 'credential-theft'], ['ransomware', 'payment']. Only include tags that are explicitly mentioned or strongly implied in the content.

associated_malware.title: Associated Malware
associated_malware.description: Names of malware families or campaigns this indicator is associated with, if mentioned in the content. Examples: ['Emotet', 'TrickBot'], ['BlackCat'], ['Cobalt Strike']. Only include if explicitly mentioned in the content.

associated_threat_actors.title: Associated Threat Actors
associated_threat_actors.description: Names of threat actors or groups this indicator is associated with, if mentioned in the content. Examples: ['APT28'], ['Lazarus Group'], ['FIN7']. Only include if explicitly mentioned in the content.

associated_vulnerabilities.title: Associated Vulnerabilities
associated_vulnerabilities.description: Names or identifiers of vulnerabilities this indicator is associated with, if mentioned in the content. Examples: ['CVE-2023-1234'], ['Log4Shell', 'CVE-2021-44228'], ['ProxyShell']. Only include if explicitly mentioned in the content.

IndicatorAnalysis.title: IndicatorAnalysis
IndicatorAnalysis.description: Extract information about a single indicator of compromise from the content.

url.title: Url
url.description: URL to ingest as a reference

IntegrationOutputModel.title: IntegrationOutputModel
IntegrationOutputModel.description: Output model for Integration list/summary views.

has_sensitive_data.title: Has Sensitive Data
has_sensitive_data.description: Indicates if sensitive data is stored (never returns actual data)

capabilities.title: Capabilities
capabilities.description: Available actions for this integration type

IntegrationUpdate.title: IntegrationUpdate
IntegrationUpdate.description: Schema for updating an existing integration.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary, most formal name of the location being discussed. Use the official or formal name when possible. Examples: New York, Paris, United States

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names, nicknames, or variants used to refer to the location as mentioned in the content. Include common abbreviations and colloquial names. Examples: ['Big Apple', 'NYC'] for New York, ['US', 'USA', 'America'] for United States

location_type.title: Location Type
location_type.description: The type or category of location being discussed. Examples: Country, State, Province, City, Region, Continent, Territory, District, County, Municipality

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the location is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'The attack targeted organizations across the United States and Canada, with particular focus on financial institutions in New York and Toronto...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview of how this location is relevant to the content. Focus on the specific context or significance mentioned. Examples: 'Primary target region for the campaign', 'Location of threat actor infrastructure', 'Affected jurisdiction'

country_code.title: Country Code
country_code.description: The ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country code for the location if it's a country or if the location can be mapped to a specific country. Use uppercase. Examples: US, CA, GB, DE, FR, JP, CN, RU. If unknown or not applicable, return None.

region.title: Region
region.description: The broader geographical region this location belongs to as mentioned in the content. Examples: North America, Europe, Asia Pacific, Middle East, Africa, Latin America, Oceania

relevance_to_threat.title: Relevance To Threat
relevance_to_threat.description: How this location is relevant to the cybersecurity threat or incident being discussed. Examples: 'Target location', 'Threat actor origin', 'Infrastructure hosting location', 'Affected region', 'Command and control location'

targeted_by_threat_actors.title: Targeted By Threat Actors
targeted_by_threat_actors.description: A list of threat actors that have targeted this location as mentioned in the content. Only include proper threat actor names, not generic terms. Examples: APT28, FIN7, Lazarus Group, BlackCat

targeted_industries.title: Targeted Industries
targeted_industries.description: A list of industries in this location that have been targeted as mentioned in the content. Examples: finance, healthcare, energy, government, technology, manufacturing

LocationAnalysis.title: LocationAnalysis
LocationAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single location mention from the content.

Use the primary, most formal name of the location. Include aliases like
nicknames and common abbreviations.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 2.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary name of the malware being discussed. Use the most commonly referenced name in the content. Make sure these are proper nouns representing specific malware families, not generic terms. Valid examples: RedLine, Emotet, TrickBot, BlackCat, LockBit, Cobalt Strike. Invalid examples: 'malware', 'ransomware', 'trojan', 'virus', 'backdoor' - these are categories, not specific malware names.

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names, variants, or family names used to refer to the malware as mentioned in the content. Make sure to include only proper names, not generic words like 'malware', 'trojan' or 'virus'. Examples: Heodo (for Emotet), Geodo, QakBot, Qbot

categories.title: Categories
categories.description: The malware family or category this malware belongs to as mentioned in the content. Examples: Banking Trojan, Ransomware, RAT, Backdoor, Loader, Stealer, Botnet

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the malware is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'Emotet has been observed distributing secondary payloads including TrickBot and Cobalt Strike beacons through malicious email campaigns...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: Can you give an overview of what the malware does or what it's known for based on this content? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'Banking trojan that steals credentials and financial information', 'Ransomware that encrypts files and demands payment', 'Remote access trojan providing persistent backdoor access'

targeted_industries.title: Targeted Industries
targeted_industries.description: A list of industries targeted by the malware as mentioned in the content. Aim for a single word. Make sure the industry was a real industry, for example 'finance', or 'healthcare', or 'crypto'. Examples: healthcare, finance, energy, technology. If unknown, return None.

is_used_in_ransomware.title: Is Used In Ransomware
is_used_in_ransomware.description: Is this malware used in ransomware operations or campaigns, even if it's not ransomware itself? This includes malware used as initial access vectors, lateral movement tools, or payload delivery mechanisms in ransomware attacks. Examples: true if the content mentions the malware being used to deploy ransomware, establish persistence for ransomware groups, or facilitate ransomware operations. False if it is explicitly stated the malware is not related to ransomware. Return None if the content does not mention ransomware usage or it cannot be determined.

associated_ransomware.title: Associated Ransomware
associated_ransomware.description: A list of ransomware names associated with this malware as mentioned in the content. Examples: 'Emotet', 'TrickBot', 'QakBot'

associated_threat_actors.title: Associated Threat Actors
associated_threat_actors.description: A list of threat actors known to use this malware as mentioned in the content. Only include proper threat actor names, not generic terms. Examples: APT28, FIN7, Lazarus Group, BlackCat

associated_vulnerabilities.title: Associated Vulnerabilities
associated_vulnerabilities.description: A list of vulnerabilities exploited by this malware as mentioned in the content. Include CVE IDs and vulnerability names. Examples: CVE-2021-34527, PrintNightmare, EternalBlue

discovery_date.title: Discovery Date
discovery_date.description: The date when this malware was first discovered or reported as mentioned in the content. Use ISO format (YYYY-MM-DD) if possible. Examples: 2023-05-15, May 2023

MalwareAnalysis.title: MalwareAnalysis
MalwareAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single named malware from the content.

Focus on specific named malware families and tools, not generic malware categories.
These are malware names, not threat actor names - threat actors use malware but are
tracked separately.

MalwareEnrichResponse.title: MalwareEnrichResponse
MalwareEnrichResponse.description: Response model for malware enrichment operation

MentionOutputModel.title: MentionOutputModel
MentionOutputModel.description: Base output model for all mentions using single table inheritance

analysis_type.description: The analysis type. Always set this to 'meta'
