content_labels.title: Content Labels
content_labels.description:
What topics does this content cover? Select all that apply. These describe the subject matter of the content.

IMPORTANT: If cyber_marketing_content is True, you MUST include 'cyber_marketing'. If cyber_intel_content is True, include 'cyber_intel' unless more specific labels apply.

Available labels:
- 'ai_security': AI/ML security, LLM security, prompt injection, model poisoning, adversarial machine learning, AI red teaming, chatbot security, model extraction, training data attacks, jailbreaking, AI guardrails
- 'api_security': API vulnerabilities, OWASP API Top 10, REST security, GraphQL security, API keys, rate limiting, broken authentication, BOLA, BFLA, API gateway security
- 'application_security': AppSec, OWASP Top 10, secure coding, SAST, DAST, IAST, code review, web application security, XSS, SQL injection, CSRF, input validation, secure SDLC, dependency scanning
- 'attack_techniques': TTPs, MITRE ATT&CK, attack methodologies, kill chain, lateral movement, privilege escalation, persistence, defense evasion, initial access, execution techniques, attack chains
- 'browser_security': Browser vulnerabilities, Chrome security, Firefox security, Safari security, browser exploits, extension security, same-origin policy, CSP bypass, browser sandboxing
- 'campaign': Coordinated attack campaigns, threat campaigns, multi-stage attacks, targeted operations, attack waves, campaign tracking, campaign infrastructure
- 'cloud_security': AWS security, Azure security, GCP security, cloud misconfigurations, S3 bucket exposure, IAM policies, CSPM, CWPP, cloud-native security, serverless security, cloud workload protection
- 'container_security': Docker security, Kubernetes security, container escapes, image vulnerabilities, pod security, service mesh, container runtime security, K8s RBAC, container hardening
- 'cryptography': Encryption, cryptographic attacks, PKI, certificates, TLS/SSL, key management, post-quantum cryptography, hash collisions, cryptanalysis, cipher weaknesses, key exchange
- 'cyber_intel': Cyber threat intelligence, CTI, threat landscape, geopolitical cyber, nation-state activity, threat briefings, intelligence reports, attribution, strategic intelligence
- 'cyber_marketing': Marketing content from security vendors, product announcements, vendor promotions, sponsored content
- 'data_breach': Data breaches, security incidents, data leaks, PII exposure, credential dumps, breach notifications, data theft, exfiltration incidents, leaked records
- 'ddos': Distributed denial of service, DDoS attacks, volumetric attacks, application layer attacks, DDoS mitigation, amplification attacks, botnets, reflection attacks, UDP floods, SYN floods
- 'defensive_techniques': Defense strategies, detection engineering, mitigation techniques, hardening, security controls, blue team, defense in depth, security architecture, countermeasures, protective measures
- 'detection_rules': Detection rules, YARA rules, Sigma rules, Snort rules, Suricata signatures, KQL queries, SPL searches, detection logic, hunting queries, detection as code, detection engineering
- 'exploit': Exploit code, proof of concept (PoC), exploitation techniques, weaponized exploits, exploit development, RCE, buffer overflow, use-after-free, heap spray, exploit chain
- 'grc': Governance, risk management, compliance frameworks, security policies, audit, NIST, ISO 27001, SOC 2, risk assessment, control frameworks, security standards
- 'ics_ot_security': Industrial control systems, SCADA, operational technology, critical infrastructure, PLCs, HMIs, Modbus, DNP3, IEC 62443, manufacturing security, energy sector security
- 'identity_security': Identity and access management (IAM), authentication, authorization, SSO, SAML, OAuth, MFA bypass, credential theft, password spraying, Kerberoasting, Active Directory attacks, LDAP
- 'incident_response': Incident response, IR playbooks, digital forensics, DFIR, memory forensics, disk forensics, evidence collection, chain of custody, triage, containment, eradication
- 'indicator_of_compromise': Indicators of compromise, IOCs, file hashes, MD5, SHA256, malicious IPs, C2 domains, malicious URLs, registry keys, mutex names, network indicators, STIX/TAXII
- 'insider_threat': Insider threats, data exfiltration, privileged user abuse, employee monitoring, DLP, user behavior analytics (UBA), malicious insiders, negligent insiders, trusted access abuse
- 'iot_security': Internet of Things security, embedded device security, smart device vulnerabilities, IoT botnets, firmware analysis, hardware hacking, IoT protocols, Zigbee, Z-Wave
- 'law_enforcement': Law enforcement actions, takedowns, arrests, indictments, seizures, international cooperation, cybercrime prosecution, FBI, Europol, infrastructure disruption
- 'malware': Malware analysis, malware families, trojans, backdoors, RATs, infostealers, wipers, loaders, droppers, reverse engineering, unpacking, sandbox analysis, static analysis, dynamic analysis
- 'mobile_security': Android security, iOS security, mobile malware, MDM, mobile app vulnerabilities, APK analysis, mobile phishing, smishing, mobile device management, app store security
- 'network_security': Network security, firewalls, IDS/IPS, network segmentation, VPN, network monitoring, packet analysis, lateral movement detection, network forensics, NDR, zero trust network
- 'patch': Security patches, software updates, Patch Tuesday, hotfixes, security advisories, CVE fixes, firmware updates, patch management, vulnerability remediation, update deployment
- 'phishing': Phishing attacks, spear phishing, phishing campaigns, credential harvesting, phishing kits, email lures, malicious attachments, phishing URLs, brand impersonation, whaling
- 'privacy': Data privacy, GDPR, CCPA, privacy engineering, PII protection, data minimization, privacy by design, surveillance, data protection, privacy regulations, consent management
- 'ransomware': Ransomware attacks, ransomware families, encryption malware, ransom notes, double extortion, ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS), data leak sites, ransom demands, decryptors, ransomware negotiations
- 'red_team': Offensive security, penetration testing, red team operations, adversary simulation, purple team, attack simulation, ethical hacking, security assessment, C2 frameworks, Cobalt Strike
- 'regulatory': Compliance news, regulatory updates, security regulations, industry mandates, legal requirements, enforcement actions, regulatory guidance, compliance deadlines
- 'security_operations': SOC operations, SIEM, SOAR, security monitoring, alert triage, runbooks, security automation, managed detection and response (MDR), security orchestration, analyst workflows
- 'social_engineering': Social engineering attacks, pretexting, baiting, quid pro quo, tailgating, vishing, business email compromise (BEC), CEO fraud, impersonation, manipulation techniques
- 'supply_chain': Supply chain attacks, dependency confusion, package poisoning, software bill of materials (SBOM), third-party risk, SolarWinds-style attacks, npm/PyPI malicious packages, vendor compromise
- 'threat_actor': Threat actor profiles, APT groups, nation-state actors, cybercrime groups, threat actor TTPs, actor attribution, threat actor infrastructure, actor tracking, adversary profiles
- 'threat_hunting': Proactive threat hunting, hypothesis-driven hunting, threat hunting methodologies, hunting queries, anomaly detection, threat hunting playbooks, hunting tools, threat discovery
- 'vulnerability': Vulnerability disclosures, CVE, security flaws, vulnerability analysis, proof of concept, vulnerability research, bug reports, security advisories, NVD, vulnerability scoring, CVSS
- 'vulnerability_management': Vulnerability management programs, prioritization, remediation workflows, VM tooling, vulnerability scanning, asset inventory, risk-based prioritization, SLA tracking, remediation metrics
- 'zero_day': Zero-day vulnerabilities, 0-day exploits, unpatched vulnerabilities, in-the-wild exploitation, responsible disclosure, zero-day attacks, unknown vulnerabilities, novel exploits
- 'behavioral_indicators': Behavioral indicators, TTPs for detection, observable behaviors, process behaviors, network behaviors, file system activity, registry modifications, command-line patterns, execution patterns

format_labels.title: Format Labels
format_labels.description:
What is the format/shape of this content? Select the most appropriate. These describe how the content is structured or presented.

Available labels:
- 'advisory': Security advisories, vulnerability notices, CVE publications, vendor security bulletins, coordinated disclosure notices
- 'blog_post': Blog articles, vendor blogs, personal security blogs, company engineering blogs, informal analysis posts
- 'book': Book content, book excerpts, ebook chapters, security book references
- 'case_study': Incident case studies, breach post-mortems, lessons learned, incident analysis, retrospectives
- 'code_repository': Source code repositories, security tools, PoC code, GitLab repos, Bitbucket repos (non-GitHub)
- 'conference_talk': Conference presentations, slides, talk transcripts (DEF CON, Black Hat, RSA, BSides, security meetups)
- 'documentation': Product documentation, API docs, security guides, configuration guides, hardening guides, runbooks
- 'forum_post': Forum discussions, Reddit posts, Stack Exchange, security community forums, dark web forum posts
- 'github_repo': GitHub repositories, README files, security tools, exploit code, PoC repositories, GitHub gists
- 'github_issue': GitHub issues, pull requests, security issue discussions, bug reports, vulnerability disclosures on GitHub
- 'legal_document': Court filings, indictments, legal complaints, DOJ announcements, regulatory filings related to cybercrime
- 'mailing_list': Security mailing lists, oss-security, Full Disclosure, Bugtraq, debian-security, vendor security lists
- 'news_article': News coverage, tech journalism, breaking news, incident reporting, mainstream media cybersecurity coverage
- 'podcast': Audio content, podcast episodes, security podcasts (Darknet Diaries, Risky Business, Security Now)
- 'press_release': Official press releases, company announcements, PR newswire, business wire, corporate communications
- 'research_paper': Academic papers, peer-reviewed research, conference papers, arXiv preprints, IEEE/ACM publications, university research
- 'social_media_post': Posts from social platforms (Twitter/X, LinkedIn, Mastodon, Bluesky), threads, social media threads
- 'technical_report': In-depth technical analysis, malware analysis reports, reverse engineering writeups, detailed forensic reports
- 'threat_report': Formal threat intelligence reports, annual threat reports, campaign reports, APT reports, landscape reports
- 'tutorial': How-to guides, walkthroughs, step-by-step instructions, educational content, CTF writeups
- 'video': Video content, YouTube videos, conference recordings, security talks, training videos, demos
- 'webinar': Online presentations, webinars, virtual events, live streams, recorded webinars
- 'whitepaper': Formal industry whitepapers, solution briefs, technical white papers, vendor position papers, thought leadership

source_type_labels.title: Source Type Labels
source_type_labels.description:
What type of source published this content? Select all that apply. These describe who created or published the content.

Available labels:
- 'academic_institution': Universities, research labs, academic security groups (MIT, Stanford, CMU, Georgia Tech, Oxford)
- 'bug_bounty_platform': Disclosures from bug bounty platforms (HackerOne, Bugcrowd, Intigriti, YesWeHack)
- 'cert_team': Computer Emergency Response Teams (CERT/CC, US-CERT, national CSIRTs, JPCERT, AusCERT)
- 'enterprise_security_team': Security teams at major tech companies (Google Project Zero, Microsoft MSRC, Apple Security, Meta Red Team)
- 'government_advisory': Official government security advisories (CISA, NCSC, NSA, FBI, ENISA, ACSC)
- 'industry_consortium': Security standards bodies, consortiums, and ISACs (MITRE, FIRST, OWASP, CIS, NIST, FS-ISAC, H-ISAC, IT-ISAC)
- 'news': Security journalists, investigative reporters, tech news outlets (Krebs on Security, Wired, Ars Technica, The Record, BleepingComputer)
- 'open_source_project': OSS security announcements, maintainer disclosures, project security advisories (GitHub Security Advisories, npm advisories, PyPI)
- 'product_advisory': Vendor security advisories for specific products (hardware, software, services, Microsoft, Cisco, Adobe, Oracle)
- 'security_researcher': Content from independent security researchers, personal blogs, conference talks, bug hunters
- 'security_vendor': Security product companies and threat intelligence providers (CrowdStrike, Palo Alto, Mandiant, Recorded Future, Sophos, Fortinet, SentinelOne)

depth_labels.title: Depth Labels
depth_labels.description:
What is the technical depth of this content? Select if applicable. These describe the level of technical detail.

Available labels:
- 'strategic': High-level trends, threat landscape, business impact, risk assessment, suitable for executives and security leadership
- 'operational': Campaign details, threat actor methods, detection strategies, suitable for security teams and analysts
- 'tactical': Specific IOCs, detection rules, exploit code, remediation steps, immediately actionable for defenders

cyber_marketing_content.title: Cyber Marketing Content
cyber_marketing_content.description: Does this content attempt to primarily market a cybersecurity product or service? Examples: Webinar about a new EDR product, Marketing material for a SIEM solution, Product demo for a vulnerability scanner. Set to true if marketing focused, false otherwise.

disparate_topics.title: Disparate Topics
disparate_topics.description: Does this content contain information about many different unrelated topics, or information about different events? Is it a rollup report? If the content primarily discusses a single threat event, actor, vulnerability, or topic, set this to false. If unknown, leave blank.

cyber_intel_content.title: Cyber Intel Content
cyber_intel_content.description: Does this content provide general information about cyber-related organizations, products, law enforcement, regulatory bodies, malware, threat actors, threat groups or other related content such as breaches, vulnerabilities, patches, ransomware, or data breaches? Examples: Content about APT28, Emotet malware, CVE-2021-44228 (Log4Shell), SolarWinds breach. Set to true if content relates to these topics. Set to false if content does not make sense to a cybersecurity researcher, lacks information about the types of entities listed above, or is unrelated to cybersecurity.

should_analyze.title: Should Analyze
should_analyze.description:
True when content has a valid analysis path.

Marketing content is always blocked. Otherwise, content
is analyzable when:
- cyber_intel_content flag is True, OR
- any topic label is in _ANALYZABLE_TOPIC_LABELS, OR
- any source_type label is in
  _ANALYZABLE_SOURCE_TYPE_LABELS, OR
- any format label is in _ANALYZABLE_FORMAT_LABELS.

MetaAnalysis.title: MetaAnalysis
MetaAnalysis.description:
Analyze the content and determine if it is related
to cyber threat intelligence and answer questions about
what type of content it is.

observable_type.title: Observable Type
observable_type.description: The observable type (e.g., 'domain', 'ip.v4', 'hash.sha256'). Must match one of the provided types in the batch.

is_valid.title: Is Valid
is_valid.description: Is this observable valid for inclusion in the threat intelligence database? The observable was extracted via regex and is confirmed present in the content. Set to False ONLY if it's a false positive (e.g., example.com, localhost, 127.0.0.1, RFC1918 private IPs, documentation hashes, legitimate security vendor domains mentioned as references, etc.). Default to True unless you can confirm it's a false positive based on the content context.

description.title: Description
description.description: A brief 1-2 sentence description explaining what this observable represents based on the content. Examples: 'Command and control domain for Emotet', 'Malicious IP hosting phishing pages', 'Hash of ransomware payload'. Only provide if is_valid is True.

verdict.title: Verdict
verdict.description: The verdict about this indicator based on how it is characterized in the content. Must be one of: 'malicious', 'benign', 'suspicious', 'unknown'. Use 'malicious' if the content explicitly identifies the indicator as malicious. Use 'suspicious' if potentially malicious but not definitive. Use 'benign' if explicitly safe. Use 'unknown' if unclear. Only provide if is_valid is True.

associated_malware.title: Associated Malware
associated_malware.description: Comma-separated list of malware families or campaigns this observable is associated with, if mentioned. Examples: 'Emotet, TrickBot', 'BlackCat'. Only provide if explicitly mentioned and is_valid is True.

associated_threat_actors.title: Associated Threat Actors
associated_threat_actors.description: Comma-separated list of threat actors this observable is associated with, if mentioned. Examples: 'APT28', 'Lazarus Group, APT38'. Only provide if explicitly mentioned and is_valid is True.

tags.title: Tags
tags.description: Comma-separated list of relevant tags. Examples: 'c2, malware', 'phishing, credential-theft', 'ransomware'. Only include tags explicitly mentioned or strongly implied. Only provide if is_valid is True.

ObservableValidation.title: ObservableValidation
ObservableValidation.description:
Validation and enrichment for a single observable extracted via regex.

The LLM determines if the observable is valid (actually mentioned as an indicator
in the content) and provides enrichment metadata.

ObservableWithVerdictCountsOutputModel.title: ObservableWithVerdictCountsOutputModel
ObservableWithVerdictCountsOutputModel.description: Observable output model with verdict counts included.

OpinionDetailOutputModel.title: OpinionDetailOutputModel
OpinionDetailOutputModel.description: Detailed output model with reference hydration.

OpinionOutputModel.title: OpinionOutputModel
OpinionOutputModel.description: Basic output model for opinions (no hydration/relationships).

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 2.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary formal name of the private sector organization being discussed. Focus on corporations, companies, vendors, security firms, financial institutions, healthcare organizations, research firms, and service providers. Exclude threat groups, ransomware groups, and software projects without a defined vendor or organization name. IMPORTANT: Do NOT use abbreviations or acronyms as the primary name. Always prefer the full organization name over abbreviations. Use 'International Business Machines' not 'IBM', 'Amazon Web Services' not 'AWS', 'Hewlett Packard Enterprise' not 'HPE'. Only use an abbreviation if no full name is available in the content and you cannot reliably determine the full name. Valid examples: Microsoft Corporation, Amazon Web Services, CrowdStrike, Apple, Google, Cisco Systems. Invalid examples: 'IBM' (use International Business Machines), 'AWS' (use Amazon Web Services), 'HPE' (use Hewlett Packard Enterprise), 'FBI', 'CISA', 'APT28', 'Lazarus Group' - abbreviations should be avoided; agencies and threat actors are tracked separately.

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names or synonyms used to refer to the organization as mentioned in the content. Include abbreviations, alternate spellings, and formal vs informal names. Examples: ['Google Inc', 'Alphabet'], ['Microsoft Corporation', 'MSFT'], ['Amazon Web Services', 'AWS']

industries.title: Industries
industries.description: The GICS 4-digit industry group code(s) that best describe this organization's primary business. Return one or more codes from: 10 Energy: 1010=Energy; 15 Materials: 1510=Materials; 20 Industrials: 2010=Capital Goods, 2020=Commercial & Professional Services, 2030=Transportation; 25 Consumer Discretionary: 2510=Automobiles & Components, 2520=Consumer Durables & Apparel, 2530=Consumer Services, 2550=Consumer Discretionary Distribution & Retail; 30 Consumer Staples: 3010=Consumer Staples Distribution & Retail, 3020=Food, Beverage & Tobacco, 3030=Household & Personal Products; 35 Health Care: 3510=Health Care Equipment & Services, 3520=Pharmaceuticals, Biotechnology & Life Sciences; 40 Financials: 4010=Banks, 4020=Financial Services, 4030=Insurance; 45 Information Technology: 4510=Software & Services, 4520=Technology Hardware & Equipment, 4530=Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment; 50 Communication Services: 5010=Telecommunication Services, 5020=Media & Entertainment; 55 Utilities: 5510=Utilities; 60 Real Estate: 6010=Equity Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs), 6020=Real Estate Management & Development Return ONLY the 4-digit numeric code strings, e.g. ['4510'] or ['4010', '4510']. If unknown, return None.

operating_countries.title: Operating Countries
operating_countries.description: ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country codes for countries where the organization operates or has a presence. Return ONLY two-letter country codes, not region or location names. Examples: US, GB, DE, JP. If unknown, return None.

organization_type.title: Organization Type
organization_type.description: The type of organization, if mentioned in the content. Examples: Corporation, Government Agency, Non-profit, University, Military, International Organization

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the organization is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'Microsoft announced a new security update for Windows systems following the discovery of vulnerabilities...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview or summary of the organization's role or significance based on the content. This should capture why the organization is relevant to the discussion. Examples: 'Major technology company that develops operating systems and cloud services', 'Government agency responsible for cybersecurity oversight'

OrganizationAnalysis.title: OrganizationAnalysis
OrganizationAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single private sector organization from the content.

Focus on private sector entities: corporations, companies, vendors, security firms,
financial institutions, healthcare organizations, research firms, and service
providers. Exclude government agencies, military units, threat groups, and software
projects (which are tracked separately).

OrganizationEnrichResponse.title: OrganizationEnrichResponse
OrganizationEnrichResponse.description: Response model for organization enrichment operation

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary, most complete name of the person being discussed. Use the full name when available. Examples: John Doe, Jane Smith, Dmitry Yuryevich

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: Alternative names, nicknames, or variants used to refer to the person as mentioned in the content. Include shortened versions and handles. Examples: ['John D', 'Johnny'] for John Doe

roles.title: Roles
roles.description: Roles, titles, or affiliations explicitly mentioned for this person in the content. Examples: 'security researcher', 'CISO at Acme Corp', 'law enforcement officer'.

context.title: Context
context.description: Snippet of text in which the person is discussed. If unknown, return None.

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: A brief overview describing why this person is relevant in the content.

PersonAnalysis.title: PersonAnalysis
PersonAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single named person from the content.

Focus on specific named individuals mentioned by name, not generic references
to roles or unnamed individuals.

analysis_type.title: Analysis Type
analysis_type.description: The analysis type. Always set this to 'product_advisory'

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 4.

advisory_id.title: Advisory Id
advisory_id.description: The unique identifier for the software advisory. Examples: 'cisco-sa-20230510-asa-ipsec', 'NETAPP-20230615-0001', 'MS23-002'

cve_ids.title: Cve Ids
cve_ids.description: A list of CVE IDs that are related to this software advisory. Examples: ['CVE-2021-44228', 'CVE-2022-22965', 'CVE-2023-23397']

vendor.title: Vendor
vendor.description: The name of the software vendor being discussed. Examples: Microsoft, Google, Cisco

advisory_version.title: Advisory Version
advisory_version.description: The version of the advisory document. Examples: '1.0', '2.1', '3.0.1'

last_updated.title: Last Updated
last_updated.description: The date when the advisory was last updated. Examples: '04/18/2025', '2023-10-15', 'January 30, 2024'

status.title: Status
status.description: The current status of the advisory. Examples: 'Final', 'Draft', 'Updated', 'Revised', 'Withdrawn'

summary.title: Summary
summary.description: A brief summary of the software advisory. This should capture the main issue being addressed. Examples: 'Remote code execution vulnerability in Exchange Server', 'Privilege escalation vulnerability in Chrome browser'

impact.title: Impact
impact.description: The potential impact if the vulnerability is exploited.

mitigation.title: Mitigation
mitigation.description: A detailed description of the recommended mitigation or workaround to address the vulnerability until a patch can be applied. Examples: 'Disable the affected service', 'Apply the vendor-provided patch', 'Implement network segmentation to limit exposure'

remediation.title: Remediation
remediation.description: A detailed description of the recommended remediation or fix to address the vulnerability. Examples: 'Upgrade to a fixed version', 'Apply the vendor-provided patch', 'Disable the affected service'

exploit_exists.title: Exploit Exists
exploit_exists.description: Indicates whether an exploit for this vulnerability exists. True if there is a known exploit available, False if it's explicitly stated no exploit exists, None if unknown.

exploited_in_the_wild.title: Exploited In The Wild
exploited_in_the_wild.description: Indicates whether this vulnerability has been actively exploited in the wild.Set to True if there are confirmed cases of exploitation or if the advisory lists the Known Exploited Vulnerability (KEV) as Yes/True. Set to False if it is explicitly stated there are no known instances of exploitation or if KEV is No/False. Set to None if exploitation status is unknown or not mentioned.

reporter.title: Reporter
reporter.description: The entity or individual who reported or discovered the vulnerability. Examples: 'Google Project Zero', 'Independent security researcher', 'Internal security team'

references.title: References
references.description: A list of URLs that provide additional information about the advisory. Examples: ['https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2023-1234', 'https://www.vendor.com/security/advisories/2023-001']

revisions.title: Revisions
revisions.description: A list of revisions to the software advisory.

vulnerable_product_configurations.title: Vulnerable Product Configurations
vulnerable_product_configurations.description: A list of product configurations that are vulnerable.

ProductAdvisoryAnalysis.title: ProductAdvisoryAnalysis
ProductAdvisoryAnalysis.description: Extract the product advisory entities from the content.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version number or identifier of the advisory revision. Examples: '1.0', '2.1', 'Rev A'

description.title: Description
description.description: A description of what changed in this revision of the advisory. Examples: 'Updated affected versions list', 'Added new mitigation steps'

section.title: Section
section.description: The specific section of the advisory that was revised. Examples: 'Affected Products', 'Mitigations', 'Impact Assessment'

status.title: Status
status.description: The current status of this revision. Examples: 'Draft', 'Published', 'Updated', 'Final'

date.title: Date
date.description: The date when this revision was made. Examples: '2023-04-15', '2022-11-30T14:22:00Z'

advisory_id.title: Advisory Id
advisory_id.description: Advisory identifier this configuration came from. Return the explicit advisory ID when available.

cve_id.title: Cve Id
cve_id.description: The primary CVE ID tied to this configuration entry. Return one CVE ID string when the advisory associates the configuration with a specific vulnerability.

part.title: Part
part.description: The product part attribute, which must be one of these three string values: 'a' for applications, 'o' for operating systems, or 'h' for hardware devices.

vendor.title: Vendor
vendor.description: The vendor attribute, which should describe or identify the person or organization that manufactured or created the product.

product.title: Product
product.description: The product attribute, which should describe or identify the most common and recognizable title or name of the product.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version attribute, which should be vendor-specific alphanumeric strings characterizing the particular release version of the product. Populate this when the advisory lists a single version. Leave it unset when the advisory specifies a version range and instead use the version range attributes below. Use the literal wildcard string '*' when the advisory explicitly states any version.

update.title: Update
update.description: The update attribute, which should be vendor-specific alphanumeric strings characterizing the particular update, service pack, or point release of the product. Use the literal wildcard string '*' when the advisory indicates any update.

version_start_excluding.title: Version Start Excluding
version_start_excluding.description: The starting version of a range, excluding the value itself. Use this only when the advisory specifies a range. Provide at most one of the start fields (excluding or including) per entry, and pair it with one of the end fields below (including or excluding).

version_start_including.title: Version Start Including
version_start_including.description: The starting version of a range, including the value itself. Use this only when the advisory specifies a range. Provide at most one of the start fields (excluding or including) per entry, and pair it with one of the end fields below (including or excluding).

version_end_excluding.title: Version End Excluding
version_end_excluding.description: The ending version of a range, excluding the value itself. Use this only when the advisory specifies a range. Provide at most one of the end fields (excluding or including) per entry; it is valid to combine either end field with either start field.

version_end_including.title: Version End Including
version_end_including.description: The ending version of a range, including the value itself. Use this only when the advisory specifies a range. Provide at most one of the end fields (excluding or including) per entry; it is valid to combine either end field with either start field.

edition.title: Edition
edition.description: The 'legacy edition' attribute (deprecated in CPE 2.3), which should capture edition-related terms applied by the vendor to the product if used. When the advisory implies any edition, return the literal wildcard string '*'.

language.title: Language
language.description: The language attribute, which must be a valid language tag (as defined by RFC5646) and should define the language supported in the user interface of the product. Use the literal wildcard string '*' when language is unspecified.

sw_edition.title: Sw Edition
sw_edition.description: The software edition attribute, which should characterize how the product is tailored to a particular market or class of end users (an extended attribute). Use the literal wildcard string '*' when the edition is unspecified.

target_sw.title: Target Sw
target_sw.description: The target software attribute, which should characterize the software computing environment within which the product operates (an extended attribute). Use the literal wildcard string '*' when the advisory does not constrain the target software.

target_hw.title: Target Hw
target_hw.description: The target hardware attribute, which should characterize the instruction set architecture (ISA), such as x86, on which the product operates; bytecode-intermediate languages are considered ISAs (an extended attribute). Use the literal wildcard string '*' when hardware architecture is unspecified.

other.title: Other
other.description: The other attribute, which should capture any other general descriptive or identifying information that is vendor- or product-specific and does not logically fit in any other attribute value; it should not be used for storing instance-specific data (an extended attribute). Use the literal wildcard string '*' when no such attribute is provided.

vulnerable.title: Vulnerable
vulnerable.description: True when the advisory explicitly states this configuration is vulnerable.

analysis_type.title: Analysis Type
analysis_type.description: The analysis type. Always set this to 'product_advisory_technology_configurations'.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

entries.title: Entries
entries.description: A list of technology configuration entries derived from the advisory. Each entry represents a unique product/version pairing from the source advisory.

ProductAdvisoryTechnologyConfigurationsA.title: ProductAdvisoryTechnologyConfigurationsAnalysis
ProductAdvisoryTechnologyConfigurationsA.description: Extract flattened technology configurations from a product advisory.

search_type.description: The type of search to perform. Options are: 'standard', 'did_you_mean'. Defaults to 'standard'.

cpe.description: Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) 2.3 string. Overrides type, vendor, and product if provided.

type.description: The type of the product (e.g., application, operating system). Defaults to 'application'.

schedule_cron_string.description: Cron expression for scheduling (e.g., '0 9 * * *' for daily at 9am)

status.title: Status
status.description: Status of the schedule, one of: active, paused

integration_uuid.title: Integration Uuid
integration_uuid.description: UUID of the Slack integration to use for notifications

mode.title: Mode
mode.description: Query mode: search, details, threat_actors, malware

filter.title: Filter
filter.description:
Filter string with optional prefix:
- `mitre_id:` for MITRE ATT&CK ID (e.g., mitre_id:T1566)
- `tactic:` for tactic (e.g., tactic:initial-access)
- `name:` for name search
- `subtechnique:true/false` for subtechnique filter
- `uuid:` for UUID
- No prefix defaults to name search

sort.title: Sort
sort.description: Field to sort by (name, mitre_attack_id, created_at, updated_at, trending_1d, trending_7d, trending_30d)

identifier.title: Identifier
identifier.description: Attack pattern identifier (UUID, MITRE ID, or name). Required for details, threat_actors, and malware modes.

filter.title: Filter
filter.description:
Filter string with optional prefix:
- `cve:` for CVE ID
- `uuid:` for UUID
- `desc:` for description (searches both description and gen_description fields)
- `gen_name:` for generated name
- No prefix defaults to description filter (searches both description fields)

sort.title: Sort
sort.description: Field to sort by (cve_id, trending_1d, trending_7d, trending_30d, created_at, updated_at, cvss_base_score, epss_score, epss_percentile)

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

ecosystem.title: Ecosystem
ecosystem.description: The ecosystem or platform the software package is part of. Examples: NPM, PyPI, Maven, Go, Rust, Cargo, Composer, NuGet, Homebrew, etc. If not mentioned or unclear, return None.

maintainer.title: Maintainer
maintainer.description: The organization or maintainer responsible for the software package. Examples: Apache Software Foundation, OpenSSL Project, Facebook/Meta, Google, CNCF, Docker Inc. If unknown or not mentioned, return None.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary, most complete package name including version if available. Focus on open source software components or packages. Examples: numpy 1.20.0, React 18.2.0, Apache Struts 2.5.10, jQuery 3.6.0, Apache Log4j, OpenSSL, Kubernetes, Docker, nginx, PostgreSQL

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names, abbreviations, or variants used to refer to the package as mentioned in the content. Examples: ['numpy'] for numpy 1.20.0, ['ReactJS', 'React'] for React 18.2.0, ['jQuery'] for jQuery 3.6.0

context.title: Context
context.description: A brief explanation of how this software package is discussed in the content. Examples: 'Vulnerable to remote code execution via deserialization', 'Used as dependency in affected application', 'Recommended for secure container deployment', 'Patched to address critical security flaw'

associated_threat_actors.title: Associated Threat Actors
associated_threat_actors.description: Names of threat actors or groups this software package is associated with, if mentioned in the content. Examples: ['APT28', 'FIN7'], ['Lazarus Group'], ['Cobalt Strike']. Only include if explicitly mentioned in the content.

associated_malware.title: Associated Malware
associated_malware.description: Names of malware families or campaigns this software package is associated with, if mentioned in the content. Examples: ['Emotet', 'TrickBot'], ['BlackCat'], ['Cobalt Strike']. Only include if explicitly mentioned in the content.

associated_vulnerabilities.title: Associated Vulnerabilities
associated_vulnerabilities.description: CVE identifiers associated with this software package, if mentioned. Examples: ['CVE-2021-44228', 'CVE-2021-45046'], ['CVE-2022-0778']. Only include if explicitly mentioned in the content.

impact_assessment.title: Impact Assessment
impact_assessment.description: Assessment of the impact or severity if mentioned in security context. Examples: 'Critical - allows remote code execution', 'High - potential data exposure', 'Medium - denial of service possible'. Only include if explicitly mentioned.

mitigation_advice.title: Mitigation Advice
mitigation_advice.description: Specific mitigation or remediation advice mentioned in the content. Examples: 'Upgrade to version 2.17.1 immediately', 'Apply workaround by setting system property', 'Remove component if not essential'. Only include if explicitly provided.

affected_versions.title: Affected Versions
affected_versions.description: List of versions affected by a vulnerability or issue, if mentioned. Examples: ['2.0-beta9', '2.14.1', '2.15.0'], ['< 1.1.1l'], ['all versions prior to 3.2.1']. Only include if explicitly mentioned in vulnerability context.

fixed_versions.title: Fixed Versions
fixed_versions.description: List of versions that fix a vulnerability or issue, if mentioned. Examples: ['2.17.1', '2.12.4', '2.3.2'], ['>= 1.1.1l'], ['3.2.1 and later']. Only include if explicitly mentioned as fixes.

SoftwarePackageAnalysis.title: SoftwarePackageAnalysis
SoftwarePackageAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single open source software component or package.

Focus on software packages, libraries, and modules - not commercial software
products (which are covered in focused_technology_products). Include version
information when available.

SourceConfigDetailOutputModel.description: Detailed model for source configuration output that includes additional metadata.

SourceConfigOutputModel.title: SourceConfigOutputModel
SourceConfigOutputModel.description: Base model for source configuration output.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 2.

analysis_type.title: Analysis Type
analysis_type.description: The analysis type. Always set this to 'summary_and_fact_extraction'

synopsis.title: Synopsis
synopsis.description: Provide 3 sentences minimum, 8 sentences maximum, summarizing the content. Only summarize the most important points from the content. Examples: 'A critical vulnerability in Log4j (CVE-2021-44228) was discovered that allows remote code execution. The flaw affects millions of Java applications and received a CVSS score of 10.0. Apache released version 2.15.0 to patch the vulnerability, while security researchers observed active exploitation in the wild.'

facts.title: Facts
facts.description: List of all facts related to the cybersecurity event. Be complete and comprehensive. No more than 30 facts. Be succinct. Include relevant entities, nouns, proper nouns like people, places, things, organizations, events, malware, threat actors, law enforcement agencies, vulnerabilities, etc. Make sure the facts are structured as full sentences with subject and predicate. Only include facts that are directly related to the cybersecurity event, and always try to extract names of entities. Examples: 'The Lazarus Group launched a new ransomware campaign targeting healthcare organizations.', 'Microsoft released an emergency patch for CVE-2023-23397 affecting Outlook.', 'The ALPHV ransomware group compromised Western Digital's systems on March 26, 2023.'

SummaryAndFactExtractionAnalysis.title: SummaryAndFactExtractionAnalysis
SummaryAndFactExtractionAnalysis.description: Extract the summary and facts from the content.

TechnologyProductAdvisoryDetailOutputMod.title: TechnologyProductAdvisoryDetailOutputModel
TechnologyProductAdvisoryDetailOutputMod.description: Model for technology product advisory details

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 2.

vendor.title: Vendor
vendor.description: The organization responsible for the product being discussed. If unknown, return None. Examples: Microsoft, Apple, Google, Cisco, Progress Software

vendor_aliases.title: Vendor Aliases
vendor_aliases.description: A list of alternative names or synonyms used to refer to the vendor as mentioned in the content. Include abbreviations and formal vs informal names. Examples: ['MSFT'] for Microsoft, ['Progress'] for Progress Software

product.title: Product
product.description: The primary, most complete product name being discussed. Do not include software packages (libraries, modules) - use focused_software_packages for those. Examples: Windows 10, iPhone 12, MoveIt, Chrome, ASA

product_aliases.title: Product Aliases
product_aliases.description: A list of alternative names, abbreviations, or variants used to refer to the product as mentioned in the content. Examples: ['Windows 10'] for Microsoft Windows 10, ['MoveIt'] for Progress Software MoveIt

versions.title: Versions
versions.description: What version of the product are discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 11.2, 16.5.1, 112.0.5615.121

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the product is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: Salesloft drift was released in 2024 and has experienced a number of customer breaches over the last year...

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: Can you give an overview of the product being discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: New security features added, Performance improvements, Critical bug fixes.

TechnologyProductAnalysis.title: TechnologyProductAnalysis
TechnologyProductAnalysis.description:
Extract commercial or open source software product entities from the content.

Focus on named software products with vendor and product name. Do not include
software packages (libraries, modules) - these are covered separately in the
software packages analyzer. Products should include the vendor name when available.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 2.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary name of the threat actor or named activity cluster group. These should be threat actor groups that use malware and ransomware as part of their operations, not malware or ransomware names themselves. Make sure these are proper nouns, not generic nouns like 'threat actors', 'bad actors', or 'hacker'. Use the most commonly referenced name in the content. Valid examples: APT1, Lazarus, APT28, Volt Typhoon, FIN7. Invalid examples: 'Ransomware', 'Malware', 'Microsoft Corporation', 'Russian influence actors', 'Threat actors', 'Chinese hackers', 'Russian state actors'. Names should not include suffixes like 'APT', 'RaaS Group', 'Team', or 'Ransomware' - strip these (e.g., 'Qilin APT' should be 'Qilin', 'Spearwing RaaS Group' should be 'Spearwing'). 'CyberArmyofRussia_Reborn1': invalid, should be 'Cyber Army of Russia Reborn'. 'Iranian state actors': invalid. 'China-linked APT groups': invalid.

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names, code names, or variants used to refer to the threat actor as mentioned in the content. Make sure to include only proper names, not generic words like 'gang', 'threat actor', 'hacker' or 'cyber terrorist'. Examples: Fancy Bear, STRONTIUM, Pawn Storm

sub_groups.title: Sub Groups
sub_groups.description: A list of sub-groups or teams within the threat actor organization as mentioned in the content. These should be distinct operational units or specialized teams that are part of the larger threat actor group. Include all sub-groups, not just the first one, and make sure these are proper nouns, not generic terms like 'sub-group' or 'team'. These are not synonyms for the threat actor group, these are distinct groups within the threat actor group.

context.title: Context
context.description: Can you provide a snippet of text in which the threat actor is discussed? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'APT28 has been observed targeting government organizations across Eastern Europe using spear-phishing campaigns with malicious attachments...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: Can you give an overview of what the threat actor is doing or what they're known for based on this content? If unknown, return None. Examples: 'Conducting ransomware attacks against healthcare organizations', 'Espionage campaigns targeting defense contractors', 'Financial fraud operations using banking trojans'

nation_state_sponsor.title: Nation State Sponsor
nation_state_sponsor.description: The name of the nation state that sponsors the threat actor, if explicitly mentioned in the content. Use alpha-2 codes (iso 3166) for countries. Examples: RU for Russia, CN for China, IR for Iran, KP for North Korea. If the content does not explicitly mention a nation state sponsor, return None.

source_countries.title: Source Countries
source_countries.description: ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country codes for countries where the content indicates the attacker originates from. Return ONLY two-letter country codes, not region or location names. Examples: RU, CN, IR, KP. If unknown, return None.

targeted_countries.title: Targeted Countries
targeted_countries.description: ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country codes for countries targeted by the threat actor as mentioned in the content. Return ONLY two-letter country codes, not region or location names. Examples: US, GB, DE, UA. If unknown, return None.

targeted_industries.title: Targeted Industries
targeted_industries.description: GICS 4-digit industry group code(s) for industries targeted by this threat actor. Codes: 10 Energy: 1010=Energy; 15 Materials: 1510=Materials; 20 Industrials: 2010=Capital Goods, 2020=Commercial & Professional Services, 2030=Transportation; 25 Consumer Discretionary: 2510=Automobiles & Components, 2520=Consumer Durables & Apparel, 2530=Consumer Services, 2550=Consumer Discretionary Distribution & Retail; 30 Consumer Staples: 3010=Consumer Staples Distribution & Retail, 3020=Food, Beverage & Tobacco, 3030=Household & Personal Products; 35 Health Care: 3510=Health Care Equipment & Services, 3520=Pharmaceuticals, Biotechnology & Life Sciences; 40 Financials: 4010=Banks, 4020=Financial Services, 4030=Insurance; 45 Information Technology: 4510=Software & Services, 4520=Technology Hardware & Equipment, 4530=Semiconductors & Semiconductor Equipment; 50 Communication Services: 5010=Telecommunication Services, 5020=Media & Entertainment; 55 Utilities: 5510=Utilities; 60 Real Estate: 6010=Equity Real Estate Investment Trusts (REITs), 6020=Real Estate Management & Development Return ONLY 4-digit numeric code strings, e.g. ['4510']. If unknown, return None.

malware_used.title: Malware Used
malware_used.description: A list of the names of malware used by the threat actor as mentioned in the content. Only include proper nouns and not names like 'malware' or 'powershell'. Examples: Conti, BlackCat, LockBit 3.0

vulnerabilities_used.title: Vulnerabilities Used
vulnerabilities_used.description: A list of the names of vulnerabilities used by the threat actor as mentioned in the content. Only include proper nouns and not names like 'vulnerability' or 'powershell'. Examples: CVE-2021-34527, PrintNightmare, Log4Shell

techniques_used.title: Techniques Used
techniques_used.description: A list of tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) used by the threat actor as mentioned in the content. Include specifics like attack methods, infiltration techniques, and operational procedures. Examples: 'Spear-phishing emails with malicious attachments', 'Compromised credentials for lateral movement', 'Double extortion tactics', 'Supply chain attacks'

ThreatActorAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single named threat actor or activity cluster group.

Focus on specific named threat actor groups, not generic references to hackers or
nation-state actors. These should be threat actor groups that use malware and
ransomware as part of their operations, not malware or ransomware names themselves.

TrendingDiffItem.title: TrendingDiffItem

trending_limit.title: Trending Limit

analysis_type.title: Analysis Type
analysis_type.description: The analysis type. Always set this to 'triage'

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the threat actor entities analysis. Set this to 6.

detailed_ttps_discussed.title: Detailed Ttps Discussed
detailed_ttps_discussed.description: Does this content provide detailed information and tactics, techniques, and procedures (TTPs) about a threat actor's campaign or activity? If unknown, leave blank.

observable_mention.title: Observable Mention
observable_mention.description: Does this content include one or more network observables or indicators in the content? Examples: domains like acme-malicious.com, IP addresses like 12.12.2.2, file hashes, URLs, email addresses and other network artifacts that could be indicators of compromise.

breach_entities.title: Breach Entities
breach_entities.description: Extract organizations that suffered from a data breach as described in the text. For each entity, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Use the full name of corporations and municipalities (e.g. 'State of Colorado' vs 'Colorado', or 'City of Minnetonka' vs 'Minnetonka'). Do not include words like 'ransomware attack' or 'breach' in the names. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most formal name of the organization - aliases: Any alternative names, abbreviations, or variants mentioned in the text Examples: {name: 'Equifax', aliases: ['Equifax.com']}, {name: 'City of Columbus', aliases: null}, {name: 'Yahoo', aliases: ['Yahoo.com', 'Yahoo, Inc']}

campaign_entities.title: Campaign Entities
campaign_entities.description: Extract all named actor intrusion set or campaign activity from the content. For each campaign, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. If no specific name is provided, you can construct a name starting with descripters and appending Campaign as the primary name. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary actor intrusion set or campaign name - aliases: Any alternative names or code names mentioned in the text Examples: {name: 'Operation Aurora Campaign', aliases: null}, {name: 'Bitcoin Email Campaign', aliases: ['Hidden Risk Campaign']}, {name: 'Game-related Applications Campaign', aliases: null}

agency_entities.title: Agency Entities
agency_entities.description: Extract all named agencies (regulatory bodies and law enforcement) from the content. Include both regulatory agencies (SEC, FDA, EPA, CISA) and law enforcement agencies (FBI, Europol, Scotland Yard). For each agency, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most commonly used name of the agency - aliases: Any alternative names, abbreviations, or full formal names mentioned Examples: {name: 'FDA', aliases: ['Food and Drug Administration']}, {name: 'FBI', aliases: ['Federal Bureau of Investigation']}, {name: 'CISA', aliases: ['Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency']}, {name: 'Europol', aliases: ['European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Cooperation']}

person_entities.title: Person Entities
person_entities.description: Extract all named people from the content. For each person, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most complete name of the person - aliases: Any alternative names, nicknames, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'John Doe', aliases: ['John D', 'Johnny']}, {name: 'Jane Smith', aliases: null}, {name: 'Dmitry Yuryevich', aliases: null}

product_entities.title: Product Entities
product_entities.description: Extract all named commercial or open source software products from the content. Do not include software packages, these are covered elsewhere For each product, provide the vendor and product name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most complete product name - aliases: Any alternative names, abbreviations, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'Microsoft Windows 10', aliases: ['Windows 10']}, {name: 'Apple iPhone 12', aliases: ['Apple iPhone']}, {name: 'Progress Software MoveIt', aliases: ['MoveIt']}

software_package_entities.title: Software Package Entities
software_package_entities.description: Extract all named open source software components or packages from the content. For each package, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most complete package name including version if available - aliases: Any alternative names, abbreviations, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'numpy 1.20.0', aliases: ['numpy']}, {name: 'React 18.2.0', aliases: ['ReactJS', 'React']}, {name: 'Apache Struts 2.5.10', aliases: null}, {name: 'jQuery 3.6.0', aliases: ['jQuery']}

location_entities.title: Location Entities
location_entities.description: Extract all location mentions from the content. For each location, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most formal name of the location - aliases: Any alternative names, nicknames, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'New York', aliases: ['Big Apple', 'NYC']}, {name: 'Paris', aliases: null}

malware_entities.title: Malware Entities
malware_entities.description: Extract all named malware from the content. For each malware, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most commonly used name of the malware - aliases: Any alternative names, variants, or family names mentioned Examples: {name: 'RedLine', aliases: null}, {name: 'Emotet', aliases: ['Heodo']}

organization_entities.title: Organization Entities
organization_entities.description: Extract named organizations from the content. Focus on private sector entities: corporations, companies, vendors, security firms, financial institutions, healthcare organizations, research firms, and service providers. Exclude government agencies, military units, threat groups, and software projects. Structure each entity with the primary formal name and any aliases mentioned. Examples: {name: 'Microsoft Corporation', aliases: ['Microsoft']}, {name: 'Amazon Web Services', aliases: ['AWS']}, {name: 'CrowdStrike', aliases: null}

attack_pattern_entities.title: Attack Pattern Entities
attack_pattern_entities.description: Extract all named Attack Patterns and TTPs (Tactics, Techniques, and Procedures) from the content. These should generally correspond with MITRE ATT&CK. For each attack pattern, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary attack pattern name or MITRE ATT&CK technique - aliases: Any alternative names, technique IDs, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'Phishing', aliases: ['T1566']}, {name: 'SQL Injection', aliases: null}

defensive_pattern_entities.title: Defensive Pattern Entities
defensive_pattern_entities.description: Extract all named defensive patterns, security controls, and mitigation techniques from the content. These should be specific defensive measures, security tools, or protective strategies mentioned. For each defensive pattern, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary defensive pattern name or security control - aliases: Any alternative names, abbreviations, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'Multi-Factor Authentication', aliases: ['MFA', '2FA']}, {name: 'Endpoint Detection and Response', aliases: ['EDR']}, {name: 'Network Segmentation', aliases: null}

threat_actor_entities.title: Threat Actor Entities
threat_actor_entities.description: Extract all named threat actors and named activity cluster groups from the content. These should be threat actor groups that use malware and ransomware as part of their operations, not malware or ransomware names themselves. Make sure these are proper nouns, not generic nouns like 'threat actors', 'bad actors', or 'hacker'. For each threat actor or cluster, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary, most commonly used name of the threat actor - aliases: Any alternative names, code names, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'APT1', aliases: null}, {name: 'Lazarus', aliases: null}, {name: 'APT28', aliases: ['Fancy Bear']}, {name: 'Volt Typhoon', aliases: null}. Invalid examples: 'Ransomware', 'Malware', 'Microsoft Corporation', 'Russian influence actors', 'Threat actors' - these are not specific named threat actor groups. Here are more examples, both valid and invalid: 'FIN7': valid. 'Chinese government': invalid. 'CyberArmyofRussia_Reborn1': invalid, should be 'Cyber Army of Russia Reborn'.

vulnerability_entities.title: Vulnerability Entities
vulnerability_entities.description: Extract all named vulnerabilities from the content. These should be specific vulnerabilities, not classes of vulnerabilities. For each vulnerability, provide the primary name and any aliases mentioned. Structure each entity with: - name: The primary vulnerability identifier (preferably CVE ID) - aliases: Any alternative names, nicknames, or variants mentioned Examples: {name: 'CVE-2021-34527', aliases: ['PrintNightmare']}, {name: 'CVE-2021-44228', aliases: ['Log4Shell']}. Invalid examples: 'CSRF', 'Cross-Site Scripting', 'SQL Injection' - these are vulnerability classes, not specific named vulnerabilities. Here are more examples, both valid and invalid: '0days': invalid. 'CVE-2021-34527': valid. 'CWE-802': invalid.

TriageAnalysis.title: TriageAnalysis
TriageAnalysis.description:
Use your deep experience and knowledge of the cybersecurity domain to answer
questions, determine specifics about the discussed event, and name the entities
described in the content.

analysis_type.title: Analysis Type
analysis_type.description: The analysis type. Always set this to 'upstream'.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the upstream analysis. Version 3 uses url_mappings from extraction pipeline.

total_extracted.title: Total Extracted
total_extracted.description: Total number of URLs from url_mappings.

total_filtered.title: Total Filtered
total_filtered.description: Number of URLs (same as extracted, filtering done in extraction).

total_validated.title: Total Validated
total_validated.description: Number of URLs validated as upstream sources by LLM.

validated_urls.title: Validated Urls
validated_urls.description: List of validated upstream URLs with classification data.

UpstreamAnalysis.title: UpstreamAnalysis
UpstreamAnalysis.description:
Upstream source URL validation using LLM.

This class validates URLs as upstream sources using LLM analysis.
It uses url_mappings from the content extraction pipeline - the clean
extracted text contains [[URL_N]] placeholders, and url_mappings provides
the mapping back to original URLs.

This approach is more token-efficient and accurate than extracting URLs
from raw HTML because:
- URLs are already extracted and filtered during content extraction
- Content is clean article text (not raw HTML with nav/footer noise)
- Placeholders show exactly where URLs were cited in context

placeholder.title: Placeholder
placeholder.description: The placeholder string (e.g., '[[URL_abc12345_1]]') that identifies this URL in the content. REQUIRED - must match exactly.

is_valid.title: Is Valid
is_valid.description: Is this URL a valid upstream source? Set to True ONLY if this URL is cited as the origin of facts, research, data, or analysis in the content. Set to False for: editorial/navigation links, tag pages, category pages, author profiles, self-referential links, social media profiles (unless cited as disclosure source), advertising/tracking URLs, and generic resources not specifically cited as sources.

relation.title: Relation
relation.description: The relation type if is_valid is True. Options: 'primary_source' (original research, advisories, papers), 'secondary_summary' (news coverage citing others), 'hat_tip' (credit to reporter/finder), 'dataset_code' (GitHub repos, PoCs, tools), 'proof_reference' (court docs, official records), 'other' (unclear or ambiguous). Only provide if is_valid is True.

evidence.description: Evidence for the classification including anchor_text and quote. Only provide if is_valid is True.

description.title: Description
description.description: Brief description of what this source provides. Examples: 'Original CISA advisory on the vulnerability', 'Researcher's blog post with technical analysis', 'GitHub repo containing PoC exploit'. Only provide if is_valid is True.

UpstreamUrlValidation.title: UpstreamUrlValidation
UpstreamUrlValidation.description:
Validation and classification for a single URL.

The LLM determines if the URL is a valid upstream source and classifies
its relation type. The placeholder field is used to match LLM responses
back to input URLs (since LLMs may reorder or omit items).

VerdictCounts.title: VerdictCounts
VerdictCounts.description: Counts of verdicts by type for an observable.

version.title: Version
version.description: The version of the analysis. Set this to 1.

name.title: Name
name.description: The primary name or identifier of the vulnerability being discussed. These should be specific vulnerabilities, not classes of vulnerabilities. Use the most commonly referenced name in the content (preferably CVE ID). Valid examples: CVE-2021-34527, CVE-2021-44228, PrintNightmare, Log4Shell. Invalid examples: 'CSRF', 'Cross-Site Scripting', 'XSS', 'SSRF', 'SQL Injection', 'CWE-802', 'Unknown Android Flaws', '0days', 'CVE' - these are vulnerability classes or generic references, not specific named vulnerabilities. 'Microsoft': invalid. 'Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)': invalid. 'CWE-802': invalid.

aliases.title: Aliases
aliases.description: A list of alternative names or identifiers specifically used to refer to the vulnerability as mentioned in the content. Include CVE IDs, common names, and other references. Examples: CVE-2021-44228, Log4Shell, Apache Log4j RCE

context.title: Context
context.description: A snippet of text in which the vulnerability is discussed. If unknown, return None. Examples: 'A critical vulnerability in Log4j allows remote code execution. The flaw affects millions of Java applications and received a CVSS score of 10.0...'

overview.title: Overview
overview.description: An overview of what this vulnerability is and why it's significant based on this content. If unknown, return 'Unknown'. Examples: 'A critical remote code execution vulnerability in Apache Log4j library', 'A privilege escalation flaw in Windows Print Spooler service', 'A buffer overflow vulnerability in OpenSSL library'

cve_id.title: Cve Id
cve_id.description: Return the CVE ID for this vulnerability if it is mentioned. Make sure the CVE name matches the format of a CVE (CVE-YYYY-*). Examples: CVE-2021-44228, CVE-2021-34527. Leave blank if no CVE ID is provided.

active_scanning.title: Active Scanning
active_scanning.description: Boolean value indicating if the content specifies that this vulnerability is actively being scanned for. Return True if content mentions active scanning activity, False if content explicitly states no scanning activity, or None if not mentioned in content.

exploit_code_exists.title: Exploit Code Exists
exploit_code_exists.description: Boolean value indicating if the content specifies that an exploit exists for this vulnerability. Return True if content mentions exploit availability, False if content explicitly states no exploit available, or None if not mentioned in content.

exploited_in_the_wild.title: Exploited In The Wild
exploited_in_the_wild.description: Boolean value indicating if the content specifies that this vulnerability has been exploited in the wild. Return True if content mentions exploitation activity, False if content explicitly states no exploitation observed, or None if not mentioned in content.

used_in_malware.title: Used In Malware
used_in_malware.description: Boolean value indicating if the content specifies that this vulnerability has been used in malware. Return True if content mentions malware usage, False if content explicitly states no malware usage, or None if not mentioned in content.

used_in_ransomware.title: Used In Ransomware
used_in_ransomware.description: Boolean value indicating if the content specifies that this vulnerability has been used in ransomware. Return True if content mentions ransomware usage, False if content explicitly states no ransomware usage, or None if not mentioned in content.

associated_malware.title: Associated Malware
associated_malware.description: List of malware names that the content specifies have used this vulnerability. This includes ransomware. Return the specific malware names mentioned (e.g., ['Emotet', 'TrickBot', 'QakBot']). Leave blank if not mentioned in content.

associated_threat_actors.title: Associated Threat Actors
associated_threat_actors.description: List of threat actor names that the content specifies have used this vulnerability. Return the specific threat actor names mentioned (e.g., ['APT41', 'Lazarus Group', 'FIN7']). Leave blank if not mentioned in content.

associated_targeted_products.title: Associated Targeted Products
associated_targeted_products.description: List of products or targets mentioned in the content that are affected by this vulnerability. Include specific product names, models, or product categories if mentioned. Examples: ['Netgear WNDR4300', 'Linksys WRT1900ACS', 'IP cameras', 'smart thermostats']. Return None or empty list if no targeted products are mentioned in the content.

patches_exist.title: Patches Exist
patches_exist.description: Boolean value indicating if the content specifies that patches exist for this vulnerability. Return True if content mentions patches are available, False if content explicitly states no patches available, or None if not mentioned in content.

mitigations_exist.title: Mitigations Exist
mitigations_exist.description: Boolean value indicating if the content specifies that mitigations exist for this vulnerability. Return True if content mentions mitigations are available, False if content explicitly states no mitigations available, or None if not mentioned in content.

VulnerabilityAnalysis.title: VulnerabilityAnalysis
VulnerabilityAnalysis.description:
Extract information about a single specific named vulnerability from the content.

Focus on specific vulnerabilities with CVE IDs or common names, not vulnerability
classes or categories like CSRF, XSS, SSRF, or SQL Injection.

VulnerabilityReferenceModel.title: VulnerabilityReferenceModel
VulnerabilityReferenceModel.description: Lightweight reference to a vulnerability for embedding in exploit responses.

product.title: Product
product.description: The name of the software product being discussed. Examples: Exchange, Chrome, ASA

affected.title: Affected
affected.description: Indicates whether the product is affected by the vulnerability. Use true if affected, false if not affected, unknown if unknown, and under_investigation if still being investigated.

affected_versions.title: Affected Versions
affected_versions.description: A list of versions of the software that are affected by the vulnerability. Examples: ['11.2', '16.5.1', '112.0.5615.121']

fixed_versions.title: Fixed Versions
fixed_versions.description: A list of versions of the software that have been fixed or patched. Examples: ['11.3', '16.6.1', '112.0.5615.122']

associated_bug_ids.title: Associated Bug Ids
associated_bug_ids.description: A list of bug IDs or tracking numbers associated with this vulnerability. Examples: ['BUG-1234', 'JIRA-5678', 'ISSUE-9012']

cpe_ids.title: Cpe Ids
cpe_ids.description: A list of CPE IDs that are specific to this product configuration. Examples: ['cpe:2.3:a:vendor:product:1.0:*:*:*:*:*:*:*']

VulnerableTechnologyProductConfiguration.title: VulnerableTechnologyProductConfigurationSetDetailOutputModel
VulnerableTechnologyProductConfiguration.description: Model for vulnerable technology product configuration set details.

Search model for vulnerable technology product configuration sets.

This search operates on the normalized join table that links:
- Vulnerabilities (searchable by CVE ID)
- Technology Product Configurations (searchable by CPE match ID)
- Configuration Sets (searchable by set ID)

Key ID types:
- set_id: Groups related CPE configurations (from NVD configuration_id)
- cpe_match_id: Unique identifier for a specific CPE configuration
- cve_id: CVE string identifier (e.g., "CVE-2024-12345")

version_match.description: The method used for version matching. Options are: 'none', 'exact', 'range', 'strict', 'loose'. Defaults to 'exact'.
version_match.title: Version Match

set_id.description: Configuration set identifier that groups related CPEs. This corresponds to 'configuration_id' from NVD data.
set_id.title: Set Id

include_set_results.description: Whether to include all configuration set members when a match is found. If true, returns all configurations in the same set as matched items.
include_set_results.title: Include Set Results

cpe.description: Common Platform Enumeration (CPE) 2.3 string. If provided, overrides type, vendor, product, and version fields.
cpe.title: Cpe

cpe_match_id.description: Unique identifier for a specific CPE configuration. This is different from set_id which groups multiple CPEs.
cpe_match_id.title: Cpe Match Id

cve_id.description: CVE identifier string to filter by.
cve_id.title: Cve Id

vulnerability_id.description: Database ID of the vulnerability record.
vulnerability_id.title: Vulnerability Id

type.description: The type of the product (a=application, o=operating system, h=hardware). Defaults to 'a' (application) if vendor/product provided without type.
type.title: Type

version.description: The exact version for 'exact' matching mode.
version.title: Version

version_start.description: Start of version range for 'range' matching mode.
version_start.title: Version Start

version_end.description: End of version range for 'range' matching mode.
version_end.title: Version End

update.description: The update/patch version of the product.
update.title: Update
